title: Phil Hogan (rugby league)
text:
Philip "Phil" G. Hogan (born 10 October 1954) is an English <a href="Physical%20therapy">sports therapist</a>, and former professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s. He played at representative level for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> and <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a>, and at club level for <a href="Holker%20Pioneers%20ARLFC">Holker Pioneers ARLFC</a>, <a href="Barrow%20Raiders">Barrow</a> (two spells) and <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a> as a or , i.e. number 11 or 12, or 13, during the era of contested <a href="Scrum%20%28rugby%29%23Rugby%20league">scrum</a>s. Followong retirement from rugby Phil started his own gym in his local town before later moving into coaching at local rugby union club Furness Rugby Club. Whilst coaching Phil helped develop many local rugby talents that went on to represent the county including players such as Philip Brockbank and Corne Els.
Background.
Phil Hogan was born and raised in <a href="Barrow-in-Furness">Barrow-in-Furness</a>, <a href="Lancashire">Lancashire</a>, England. Younger brother of Steve Hogan whose outstanding contributions to the Barrow team led to the coach giving Phil his chance for the 1st team at age 15 in the hopes he would be as good as Steve.
Playing career.
1977-1979 Great Britain International
1979 Great Britain Lions Tour of Australia & New Zealand 
1977 World Cup Finalist
1978 World Record Transfer Fee (Barrow to Hull KR)
1979 England International
1983/84,1984/85 RL Championship Winner
1979/80 RL Challenge Cup Winner
1980/81 RL Premiership Winner (Try scorer in the final) 
1984/85 John Player Trophy Winner (Try scorer in the final) 
1985/86 Yorkshire Cup Winner
International honours.
Phil Hogan won a <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a> for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a> while at Hull Kingston Rovers in 1979 against France, and won <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a>s for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> while at Barrow in the <a href="1977%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1977 Rugby League World Cup</a> against France, New Zealand, and Australia (2 matches), in 1978 against Australia (sub), while at Hull Kingston Rovers in 1979 against Australia, Australia (sub), New Zealand, and New Zealand (sub).
Challenge Cup Final appearances.
Phil Hogan was an <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Interchange">interchange</a>/<a href="Substitution%20%28sport%29">substitute</a> in <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a>' 10–5 victory over <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> in the <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Challenge%20Cup">1979–80</a> <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%23Challenge%20Cup">1979–80 season</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley Stadium</a>, London on Saturday 3 May 1980, in front of a crowd of 95,000, and played left-, i.e. number 4, in the 9–18 defeat by <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a> in the <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20Challenge%20Cup">1980–81</a> <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%23Challenge%20Cup">1980–81 season</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley Stadium</a>, London on Saturday 2 May 1981, in front of a crowd of 92,496.
County Cup Final appearances.
Phil Hogan played left-, i.e. number 4, and scored 2-<a href="Goal%20%28sport%29%23Rugby%20football">goal</a>s in <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a>' 7–8 defeat by <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a> in the <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20Yorkshire%20Cup">1980–81</a> <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1979–80 season</a> at <a href="Fartown%20Ground">Fartown Ground</a>, <a href="Huddersfield">Huddersfield</a> on Saturday 8 November 1980, and played right-, i.e. number 12, (replaced by <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Interchange">interchange</a>/<a href="Substitution%20%28sport%29">substitute</a> <a href="Andy%20Kelly%20%28rugby%20league%29">Andy Kelly</a>) in the 22–18 victory over <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford</a> in the <a href="1985%E2%80%9386%20Yorkshire%20Cup">1985–86</a> <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1985%E2%80%9386%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1985–86 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Sunday 27 October 1985.
Premiership Trophy Final appearances.
Phil Hogan played left-, i.e. number 4, in and scored a try <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a>' 11–7 victory over <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> in the <a href="Rugby%20League%20Premiership">Premiership</a> Final during the <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1980–81 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Saturday 16 May 1981.
BBC2 Floodlit Trophy Final appearances.
Phil Hogan played in <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a>' 3–13 defeat by <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> in the <a href="1979%20BBC2%20Floodlit%20Trophy">1979</a> <a href="BBC2%20Floodlit%20Trophy">BBC2 Floodlit Trophy</a> Final during the <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1979–80 season</a> at <a href="The%20Boulevard%20%28stadium%29">The Boulevard</a>, <a href="Kingston%20upon%20Hull">Hull</a> on Tuesday 18 December 1979.
John Player/John Player Special Trophy Final appearances.
Phil Hogan played left-, i.e. number 4, in <a href="Hull%20Kingston%20Rovers">Hull Kingston Rovers</a>' 4–12 defeat by <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> in the <a href="1981%E2%80%9382%20League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">1981–82</a> <a href="League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">John Player Trophy</a> Final during the <a href="1981%E2%80%9382%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1981–82 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Saturday 23 January 1982, and played right-, i.e. number 12, and scored a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> in the 12–0 victory over <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> in the <a href="1984%E2%80%9385%20League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">1984–85</a> <a href="League%20Cup%20%28rugby%20league%29">John Player Special Trophy</a> Final during the <a href="1984%E2%80%9385%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1984–85 season</a> at <a href="Boothferry%20Park">Boothferry Park</a>, <a href="Kingston%20upon%20Hull">Kingston upon Hull</a> on Saturday 26 January 1985.
Club career.
Phil Hogan was transferred from Barrow to Hull Kingston Rovers in 1978 for a then <a href="Rugby%20league%20transfer%20record">world record fee</a> of £33,000 (based on increases in average earnings, this would be approximately £249,700 in 2013).
